newsitem.title: UK: "Neural" computer program digs up metal deposits.
newsitem.headline: "Neural" computer program digs up metal deposits.

text.p: A self-teaching computer program has been launched which trawls through reams of data to spot metal deposits in days where it would take a team of mining geologists months, its developers said on Monday.
Britain's Neural Technologies Ltd, a privately-owned company, said Prospect Explorer has attracted an enthusiastic response from experts who have practised with the new program.

"There has only been massive enthusiasm," said Peter Baxendale, commercial director of Neural Technologies, which developed Prospect Explorer with Australian copper and gold mine Straits Resources. "Nobody has seen anything like it."
The patented program, which has been developed over the past three years, can run on a simple personal computer and will cost about 40,000 pounds for an annual licence.
A more sophisticated and faster version will be available in the summer at 200,000 to 250,000 pounds per licence.

Prospect Explorer, whose "neural technology" means it learns from experience like the brain, processes all kinds of data, such as soil chemistry, radioactivity and magnetism, to detect geological patterns and anomalies overnight.
Further analysis of the anomalies may reveal within a week whether an area has mining potential.
To test Prospect Explorer, Straits Resources used it to investigate a 100 square-kilometre plot where it was already active.
Within six days the programme found Straits Resources' Girlambone copper mine and several other potential sites.
It had taken a team of up to eight Straits Resources geologists using coventional data analysis two months to complete their own investigation of the region.
At a presentation in London, Neural Technologies Ltd said mines can reduce the time from selecting land to actual drilling by about 25 times if they use Prospect Explorer.
"This saves time...and mines will have to do much less test drilling, which is very expensive," Baxendale told journalists.
Prospect Explorer will be marketed by a joint venture recently set up by Neural Technology and Straits Resources.
Straits will have 70 percent of the Neural Mining Solutions venture, while Neural Technologies holds the rest.
Neural Mining Solutions is already in talks with "several leading mining houses" to sell Prospect Explorer, Baxendale said.
